topics.description: Details the way in which the text of the constitution can be formally amended. This is distinct from the task of constitutional interpretation often undertaken by courts.
topics.label: Constitution amendment procedure

topics.description: Some provisions in the constitutions may be so fundamental to the constitutional order, or so politically contentious, that they are designated as unamendable. In such cases, unamendable provisions are expressly noted in the constitution.
topics.label: Unamendable provisions

topics.description: Clarifies the citizenship status of members of indigenous groups. In some cases indigenous groups may be granted citizenship in a sub-national unit.
topics.label: Citizenship of indigenous groups

topics.description: Describes the conditions under which a government is allowed to revoke an individual's citizenship. Some constitutions expressly forbid the government from revoking citizenship, regardless of the circumstances.
topics.label: Conditions for revoking citizenship

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their nationality. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of nationality

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their country or place of origin. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of origin

topics.description: In extraordinary circumstances, usually relating to criminal convictions abroad, some constitutions give the government the power to deport citizens. In other constitutions, the government is specifically prohibited from deporting citizens but allows deportation of other residents.
topics.label: Power to deport citizens

topics.description: Details the requirements for an individual to be granted citizenship at birth. The requirements may relate to the citizenship or residency of one or both parents, or to the location of an individual's birth.
topics.label: Requirements for birthright citizenship

topics.description: Naturalization is the process through which a person acquires a citizenship to which they did not have a right by birth. These provisions detail the requirements an individual must fulfil in order to gain citizenship.
topics.label: Requirements for naturalization

topics.description: Primarily concerned with the movements of foreign nationals, describes the powers of the government to restrict entry into or exit out of the state.
topics.label: Restrictions on entry or exit

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to renounce their citizenship. This right is sometimes subject to qualifications relating to dual-citizenship, or the existence of a state of war.
topics.label: Right to renounce citizenship

topics.description: Clarifies the citizenship status of members of indigenous groups. In some cases indigenous groups may be granted citizenship in a sub-national unit.
topics.label: Citizenship of indigenous groups

topics.description: Grants indigenous peoples an exemption from taxation by the central government.
topics.label: Indigenous right not to pay taxes

topics.description: Grants indigenous peoples the right to take part in activities that are illegal for the non-indigenous population.
topics.label: Indigenous right to illegal activities

topics.description: Grants indigenous peoples the right to form political parties on the basis of group identity.
topics.label: Indigenous right to political parties

topics.description: Grants indigenous peoples the right to representation in the central government. This might, for example, involve a seat quota in the legislature.
topics.label: Indigenous right to representation

topics.description: Grants indigenous peoples limited rights to self-government, particularly with regard to issues that affect their territory.
topics.label: Indigenous right to self governance

topics.description: Specifically grants indigenous peoples the right to vote in national elections or referenda.
topics.label: Indigenous right to vote

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their language. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of language

topics.description: Establishes the official languages of the state. Official languages are those used for interactions with state agencies. National languages are often local languages, while the official languages of the state sometimes include the language of a former colonial power.
topics.label: Official or national languages

topics.description: Protects the right of individuals to use their native language, or otherwise provides general protections for particular languages. Protected languages may be specified, but remain distinct from the official languages of the state.
topics.label: Protection of language use

topics.description: Grants individuals charged with an offense the right to have their trial conducted in a language they understand, or the right to have an interpreter. In some cases, this would include a right to be informed of the reasons for one’s arrest.
topics.label: Trial in native language of accused

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their race. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of race

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their tribe or clan. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of tribe or clan

topics.description: Minority ethnic communities are enabled to participate in the affairs of the state or society. Some constitutions offer additional protection against forced assimilation.
topics.label: Integration of ethnic communities

topics.description: The state is required to provide additional resources, either in monetary contributions or in services, to specific groups within the society. Categories might include gender, ethnicity, disability, or any other group identity.
topics.label: Provisions for wealth redistribution

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their creed, belief, or opinions. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of creed or belief

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their religion. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of religion

topics.description: Courts with limited jurisdiction to adjudicate matters arising in religious law. Jurisdiction may be limited on a confessional basis.
topics.label: Establishment of religious courts

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to hold religious beliefs, and to freely practice those religious beliefs. This right is also commonly understood to include the right to change one's religion, or to have no religion at all.
topics.label: Freedom of religion

topics.description: An invocation of the divine. Often found in the preamble, particularly in states with an established religion.
topics.label: God or other deities

topics.description: Establishment of an official religion, or religions, for the state. Other constitutions provide special treatment for certain religions, or conversely, expressly forbid the state from establishing an official religion.
topics.label: Official religion

topics.description: Guarantees separation between the state and religious organizations. The state may be forbidden from extending governmental recognition or assistance to religious organizations.
topics.label: Separation of church and state

topics.description: Religious law and constitutional law interact in complex ways. Constitutions can treat religious law as entirely separate, integrated to some degree, applied in areas where secular law is silent, considered superior, or used as a source or inspiration for secular law.
topics.label: Status of religious law

topics.description: Religious organizations are granted a special status with regard to taxation. This may include exemptions from regular taxation of income or property.
topics.label: Tax status of religious organizations

topics.description: An independent commission responsible for facilitating and regulating elections. May be responsible for monitoring political parties and the financing of elections.
topics.label: Electoral commission

topics.description: Establishes the competencies of the electoral court. In addition to hearing challenges of election results, the court may be responsible for certifying various aspects of elections, including voter rolls and final vote tallies.
topics.label: Electoral court powers

topics.description: In cases where a judge has committed a crime, or otherwise compromised the integrity of their office, he or she may be removed from office. This may be carried out by the legislature, the executive, or another competent body.
topics.label: Electoral court removal

topics.description: The procedure through which a candidate for an electoral court judgeship is nominated and approved.  This might involve approval from the executive, and all or part of the legislature.
topics.label: Electoral court selection

topics.description: The number of years that an electoral judge serves before either reappointment or dismissal is required.
topics.label: Electoral court term length

topics.description: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve as a judge in an electoral court.
topics.label: Electoral court term limits

topics.description: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve as a judge in an electoral court. These often concern educational and professional credentials.
topics.label: Eligibility for electoral court judges

topics.description: The minimum age that an individual must have attained before assuming the office of judge in the electoral court.
topics.label: Minimum age of electoral court judges

topics.description: Rules that political parties and candidates must follow in financing electoral campaigns. Some constitutions establish government assistance for such purposes, or forbid receipt of funds from certain other sources.
topics.label: Campaign financing

topics.description: Provides for the enumeration of residents periodically. Additional instructions about the conduct of the census may also be given.
topics.label: Census

topics.description: Describes characteristics, or rules for the establishment, of electoral districts. Constitutions rarely directly establish the districts, but rather describe where and how these decisions will be made.
topics.label: Electoral districts

topics.description: When elections shall be held. This could be described in terms of a particular day, an interval between elections, or with relation to the dismissal of the legislature or executive.
topics.label: Scheduling of elections

topics.description: Voting takes place in such a way that a citizen completes the ballot privately, and the ballot cannot be connected to the voter.
topics.label: Secret ballot

topics.description: Requires all citizens to be a member of a political party, or of the sole political party of the state.
topics.label: Duty to join a political party

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their political party membership or political opinions. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of political party

topics.description: Grants indigenous peoples the right to form political parties on the basis of group identity.
topics.label: Indigenous right to political parties

topics.description: A particular political party, or type of party, has a special status within the state.
topics.label: Preferred political parties

topics.description: Certain political parties, or parties with particular ideologies or characteristics, are prohibited. For example, some constitutions prohibit parties that are founded on a tribal or group identity.
topics.label: Prohibited political parties

topics.description: Describes which branch or body of the government has the power to regulate political parties, particularly those tasked with determining the unconstitutionality of certain parties.
topics.label: Regulation of political parties

topics.description: Establishes the boundaries of acceptable activity, or the organizational structure, of political parties. For example, parties may be bound to respect some fundamental principles of the state.
topics.label: Restrictions on political parties

topics.description: Establishes the right to join a party or other political organization, or gives citizens the right to form new political parties.
topics.label: Right to form political parties

topics.description: Allows private citizens to propose new legislation. Usually this requires additional qualifications, such as support from a political party, a member of the legislature, or a certain number of signatures from other citizens.
topics.label: Legislative initiatives by citizens

topics.description: Provides citizens an opportunity to vote for or against a specific piece of proposed legislation. Referenda are proposed by one or more bodies of the government.
topics.label: Referenda

topics.description: The right to vote is held by all citizens. There may nevertheless be some restrictions on voting by residency, age, residency or criminal conviction.
topics.label: Claim of universal suffrage

topics.description: Makes voting mandatory for at least some electors in some elections. This is sometimes qualified on the basis of age, for example after age eighteen, or until age 70.
topics.label: Compulsory voting

topics.description: Specifically grants indigenous peoples the right to vote in national elections or referenda.
topics.label: Indigenous right to vote

topics.description: Even where voting is considered to be a universal right, there may be some qualifications. For example, restrictions on the basis of residency, age, or criminal convictions are common.
topics.label: Restrictions on voting

topics.description: Cabinet members generally serve at the pleasure of the appointing power, typically the executive. Many constitutions also allow the legislative branch to remove cabinet members in cases of misconduct.
topics.label: Cabinet removal

topics.description: Establishes the bodies competent to nominate and approve members of the cabinet. Appointment is usually made by the executive branch, and is in some cases subject to approval by the legislative branch.
topics.label: Cabinet selection

topics.description: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve in the cabinet. This is sometimes as simple as eligibility to vote, but may include a number of requirements. Ministers may also be restricted from serving as legislators.
topics.label: Eligibility for cabinet

topics.description: The body of high ranking officials who act as the heads of government departments and advise the head of state or head of government.
topics.label: Establishment of cabinet/ministers

topics.description: Matters on which the executive’s ministers have the power to act. These powers are often expressed in very general terms, but in some cases additional powers are enumerated for exercise in particular contexts.
topics.label: Powers of cabinet

topics.description: Cabinet members generally serve at the pleasure of the appointing power, typically the executive. Many constitutions also allow the legislative branch to remove cabinet members in cases of misconduct.
topics.label: Cabinet removal

topics.description: Closely related to the idea of separation of powers, this is a constitutional guarantee of the independence of the executive.
topics.label: Claim of executive independence

topics.description: Establishes ultimate control of the state's armed forces. Usually the head of state or head of government. This may be a ceremonial role, or may involve significant decision-making power.
topics.label: Designation of commander in chief

topics.description: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve in the cabinet. This is sometimes as simple as eligibility to vote, but may include a number of requirements. Ministers may also be restricted from serving as legislators.
topics.label: Eligibility for cabinet

topics.description: Allows the head of government, or exceptionally the cabinet, to enact rules without following the usual channels for the passage of legislation. This power is usually limited to particular circumstances or areas of government activity.
topics.label: Head of government decree power

topics.description: Protection, whether absolute or limited, against prosecution for the head of government. This may involve protection against prosecution for certain kinds of crimes, or for a specified period of time.
topics.label: Head of government immunity

topics.description: Specific, enumerated powers that are given to the head of government. For example, some heads of government are given the power to issue currency, grant asylum, award decorations, or various other particular powers.
topics.label: Head of government powers

topics.description: In cases where the head of government has committed a crime, or lost the confidence of the legislature, he or she may be removed from office. This may be carried out by the legislature, the head of state, or another competent body.
topics.label: Head of government removal

topics.description: Allows the head of state to enact rules without following the usual channels for the passage of legislation. This power is usually limited to particular circumstances or areas of government activity.
topics.label: Head of state decree power

topics.description: Specific, enumerated powers that are given to the head of state. For example, some heads of state are given the power to issue currency, grant asylum, award decorations, or various other particular powers.
topics.label: Head of state powers

topics.description: In cases where the head of state has committed a crime, or lost the confidence of the legislature, he or she may be removed from office. This may be carried out by the legislature, the head of government, or another competent body.
topics.label: Head of state removal

topics.description: Mechanisms that allow the legislative branch to ensure that executive agencies are enforcing the laws according to the intent of the legislature. Also provides a check on the misuse or abuse of executive power.
topics.label: Legislative oversight of the executive

topics.description: Protections from removal for the head of government. For example, a failed attempt to remove the head of government may preclude additional votes on the matter for a specified period of time.
topics.label: Limits on removing head of government

topics.description: Gives a body within the executive branch the authority to overrule a criminal conviction.
topics.label: Power to pardon

topics.description: Matters on which the executive’s ministers have the power to act. These powers are often expressed in very general terms, but in some cases additional powers are enumerated for exercise in particular contexts.
topics.label: Powers of cabinet

topics.description: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve as the head of government. This is sometimes as simple as eligibility to vote, but may include a number of requirements.
topics.label: Eligibility for head of government

topics.description: Allows the head of government, or exceptionally the cabinet, to enact rules without following the usual channels for the passage of legislation. This power is usually limited to particular circumstances or areas of government activity.
topics.label: Head of government decree power

topics.description: Protection, whether absolute or limited, against prosecution for the head of government. This may involve protection against prosecution for certain kinds of crimes, or for a specified period of time.
topics.label: Head of government immunity

topics.description: Specific, enumerated powers that are given to the head of government. For example, some heads of government are given the power to issue currency, grant asylum, award decorations, or various other particular powers.
topics.label: Head of government powers

topics.description: In cases where the head of government has committed a crime, or lost the confidence of the legislature, he or she may be removed from office. This may be carried out by the legislature, the head of state, or another competent body.
topics.label: Head of government removal

topics.description: The procedure by which the head of government is replaced in the event that he or she does not complete his or her term. This might involve a predetermined succession, or reversion to the normal selection procedure.
topics.label: Head of government replacement

topics.description: The procedure through which a candidate for the office of head of government is nominated and approved. This typically involves approval from both the legislature and the head of state.
topics.label: Head of government selection

topics.description: The number of years that a head of government serves before either reappointment or dismissal is required.
topics.label: Head of government term length

topics.description: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve in the office of head of government.
topics.label: Head of government term limits

topics.description: Establishes whether the head of government is required to serve, or is prohibited from serving, as a member of the legislature.
topics.label: Head of government's role in the legislature

topics.description: Protections from removal for the head of government. For example, a failed attempt to remove the head of government may preclude additional votes on the matter for a specified period of time.
topics.label: Limits on removing head of government

topics.description: The minimum age that an individual must have attained before assuming the office of head of government.
topics.label: Minimum age of head of government

topics.description: In addition to a cabinet, other councils of high ranking officials may advise the head of state. This could include a privy council to a monarch, for example. Some advisory bodies may consult on specific topics, such as national security.
topics.label: Advisory bodies to the head of state

topics.description: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve as the head of government. This is sometimes as simple as eligibility to vote, but may include a number of requirements.
topics.label: Eligibility for head of state

topics.description: Allows the head of state to enact rules without following the usual channels for the passage of legislation. This power is usually limited to particular circumstances or areas of government activity.
topics.label: Head of state decree power

topics.description: Protection, whether absolute or limited, against prosecution for the head of state. This may involve protection against prosecution for certain kinds of crimes, or for a specified period of time.
topics.label: Head of state immunity

topics.description: Specific, enumerated powers that are given to the head of state. For example, some heads of state are given the power to issue currency, grant asylum, award decorations, or various other particular powers.
topics.label: Head of state powers

topics.description: In cases where the head of state has committed a crime, or lost the confidence of the legislature, he or she may be removed from office. This may be carried out by the legislature, the head of government, or another competent body.
topics.label: Head of state removal

topics.description: The procedure by which the head of state is replaced in the event that he or she does not complete his or her term. This might involve a predetermined succession, or reversion to the normal selection procedure.
topics.label: Head of state replacement

topics.description: The procedure through which a candidate for the office of head of state is nominated and approved. While there is great variation, common procedures include heredity, direct election, or election by the legislature.
topics.label: Head of state selection

topics.description: The number of years that a head of state serves before either reappointment or dismissal is required.
topics.label: Head of state term length

topics.description: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve in the office of head of state
topics.label: Head of state term limits

topics.description: The minimum age that an individual must have attained before assuming the office of head of state.
topics.label: Minimum age of head of state

topics.description: Establishes ultimate control of the state's armed forces. Usually the head of state or head of government. This may be a ceremonial role, or may involve significant decision-making power.
topics.label: Designation of commander in chief

topics.description: A duty to serve a specified period of time in the country's military. Often also includes protections for conscientious objectors.
topics.label: Duty to serve in the military

topics.description: Allows the government to declare an exceptional state, such as emergency, siege, or martial law. Usually gives the government additional powers, and may suspend some normal functions of the political system.
topics.label: Emergency provisions

topics.description: Courts with jurisdiction limited to charges against members of the military, and tasked with enforcing military law.
topics.label: Establishment of military courts

topics.description: The process that the government must follow in order to establish a declaration of war. For example, this could be a power of the head of state, of the cabinet as a whole, or it could require consent from the legislative branch.
topics.label: Power to declare/approve war

topics.description: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve as the minister of defense. Particularly concerned with whether the minister is required to be, or prohibited from being, a member of the military.
topics.label: Restrictions on minister of defense

topics.description: Limitations either on the government's use of the military, or on the actions of members of the military. For example, prohibition of domestic deployment of the military, or restrictions on the political rights of military officers.
topics.label: Restrictions on the armed forces

topics.description: The selection process for the highest ranking officers in the military. This often involves appointment by the head of the executive branch, and in some cases also requires the approval of at least part of the legislature.
topics.label: Selection of active-duty commanders

topics.description: Terrorism specifically mentioned, usually in the context of the criminal justice system, or with regard to the activities of the military or other public safety bodies.
topics.label: Terrorism

topics.description: The office responsible for representing the government in criminal or civil cases. The office may have various names, including the public prosecutor, or prosecutor general.
topics.label: Attorney general

topics.description: Specification of the deputy to the head of state or head of government. The deputy executive typically has the power to act when the executive is absent or becomes incapable of holding office.
topics.label: Deputy executive

topics.description: The body of high ranking officials who act as the heads of government departments and advise the head of state or head of government.
topics.label: Establishment of cabinet/ministers

topics.description: Distinguishes the structure of the executive. Establishes the offices of head of state and/or head of government.
topics.label: Name/structure of executive(s)

topics.description: In federal countries, the power of the federal government to review legislation passed by the governments of the subnational units. Such review could be undertaken by a federal court or another part of the federal government.
topics.label: Federal review of subnational legislation

topics.description: Establishes which level of government has supremacy in cases where their laws conflict.
topics.label: National vs subnational laws

topics.description: Allows the state to incorporate new territory into the country. Usually also specifies the necessary steps for this to happen.
topics.label: Accession of territory

topics.description: Addresses secession or withdrawal of groups or territories of the state. In cases where secession is allowed, usually also specifies the legal process that must take place.
topics.label: Secession of territory

topics.description: Establishes the organs of municipal or local government, and their competencies.
topics.label: Municipal government

topics.description: Specifies the competencies of the governments of the subsidiary units in a federal system.
topics.label: Subsidiary unit government

topics.description: Reference to customary international law, the law of nations, or the generally accepted principles of international law.
topics.label: Customary international law

topics.description: Reference to one or more specific international treaties or instruments concerning human rights.
topics.label: International human rights treaties

topics.description: Reference to international law, including treaties, agreements, norms, or other commitments.
topics.label: International law

topics.description: Reference to international organizations, whether generally or with regard to specific international organizations such as the United Nations.
topics.label: International organizations

topics.description: Indicates the government official or body authorized to speak for the state abroad. This function could be fulfilled by the head of state, or by another government official such as the foreign minister.
topics.label: Foreign affairs representative

topics.description: The process that the government must follow in order to establish a declaration of war. For example, this could be a power of the head of state, of the cabinet as a whole, or it could require consent from the legislative branch.
topics.label: Power to declare/approve war

topics.description: Reference to one or more specific international treaties or instruments concerning human rights.
topics.label: International human rights treaties

topics.description: This especially concerns the status of treaties with regard to the constitution or ordinary law, and determines whether treaties are superior or inferior to the constitution or ordinary law.
topics.label: Legal status of treaties

topics.description: The steps that the government must follow to gain approval for accession to a treaty. Commonly this involves gaining the consent of part or all of the legislature.
topics.label: Treaty ratification

topics.description: The procedure through which a candidate for an administrative judgeship is nominated and approved. This might involve approval from the executive, and all or part of the legislature.
topics.label: Administrative court selection

topics.description: The number of years that an administrative judge serves before either reappointment or dismissal is required.
topics.label: Administrative court term length

topics.description: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve as a judge in an administrative court.
topics.label: Administrative court term limits

topics.description: Conditions that an individual must fulfil in order to serve as a judge in an administrative court. These often concern educational and professional credentials.
topics.label: Eligibility for administrative  judges

topics.description: Courts that adjudicate disputes about the government's exercise of power in ordinary administrative functions.
topics.label: Establishment of administrative courts

topics.description: The minimum age that an individual must have attained before assuming the office of judge in an administrative court.
topics.label: Min age of administrative judges

topics.description: Protects individuals from the use of excess power by administrative agencies of the government. Commonly also establishes procedures for review of such actions and provides redress for those harmed.
topics.label: Ultra-vires administrative actions

topics.description: Determines procedures for, or treatment of, judicial opinions handed down by the constitutional court.
topics.label: Constitutional court opinions

topics.description: Establishes the competencies of the constitutional court, other than adjudication and review of legislation. Such powers may include supervision of elections, impeachment of the executive, review of treaties, or other specified functions.
topics.label: Constitutional court powers

topics.description: In cases where a judge has committed a crime, or otherwise compromised the integrity of their office, he or she may be removed from office. This may be carried out by the legislature, the executive, or another competent body.
topics.label: Constitutional court removal

topics.description: The procedure through which a candidate for a constitutional court judgeship is nominated and approved.  This might involve approval from the executive, and all or part of the legislature.
topics.label: Constitutional court selection

topics.description: The number of years that a constitutional court judge serves before either reappointment or dismissal is required.
topics.label: Constitutional court term length

topics.description: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve as a judge in a constitutional court.
topics.label: Constitutional court term limits

topics.description: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve as a judge in a constitutional court. These often concern educational and professional credentials.
topics.label: Eligibility for const court judges

topics.description: A court that is especially empowered to interpret the constitution, and usually to rule on whether legislation is in accord with the principles of the constitution.
topics.label: Establishment of constitutional court

topics.description: The minimum age that an individual must have attained before assuming the office of judge in a constitutional court.
topics.label: Min age of const court judges

topics.description: Establishes the competencies of the electoral court. In addition to hearing challenges of election results, the court may be responsible for certifying various aspects of elections, including voter rolls and final vote tallies.
topics.label: Electoral court powers

topics.description: In cases where a judge has committed a crime, or otherwise compromised the integrity of their office, he or she may be removed from office. This may be carried out by the legislature, the executive, or another competent body.
topics.label: Electoral court removal

topics.description: The procedure through which a candidate for an electoral court judgeship is nominated and approved.  This might involve approval from the executive, and all or part of the legislature.
topics.label: Electoral court selection

topics.description: The number of years that an electoral judge serves before either reappointment or dismissal is required.
topics.label: Electoral court term length

topics.description: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve as a judge in an electoral court.
topics.label: Electoral court term limits

topics.description: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve as a judge in an electoral court. These often concern educational and professional credentials.
topics.label: Eligibility for electoral court judges

topics.description: The minimum age that an individual must have attained before assuming the office of judge in the electoral court.
topics.label: Minimum age of electoral court judges

topics.description: Establishes the competencies of the constitutional court, other than adjudication and review of legislation. Such powers may include supervision of elections, impeachment of the executive, review of treaties, or other specified functions.
topics.label: Constitutional court powers

topics.description: In cases where a judge has committed a crime, or otherwise compromised the integrity of their office, he or she may be removed from office. This may be carried out by the legislature, the executive, or another competent body.
topics.label: Constitutional court removal

topics.description: Describes which bodies of government are empowered to interpret the constitution. This is commonly the role of a constitutional court or supreme court, but in some cases is a responsibility of all or a part of the legislature.
topics.label: Constitutional interpretation

topics.description: Procedures for examining whether the content of a piece of legislation is in accord with the constitution. This may or may not be permissible prior to the promulgation of the legislation.
topics.label: Constitutionality of legislation

topics.description: An explicit declaration that judges are autonomous or the judiciary as a whole is independent. This may include protection from outside influence on their decision making, particularly from other branches of the government.
topics.label: Judicial independence

topics.description: A requirement that judges must at least take into account, and potentially follow, precedents set by rulings in higher courts.
topics.label: Judicial precedence

topics.description: Specifies the age at which judges must step down. A common alternative to term limits.
topics.label: Mandatory retirement age for judges

topics.description: Prevents tampering with the salaries of judges for political ends. Can bolster judicial independence.  Provisions about protection of the overall judicial budget are included here.
topics.label: Protection of judges' salaries

topics.description: Establishes the competencies of the supreme court, other than adjudication and review of legislation. Such powers may include supervision of elections, impeachment of the executive, review of treaties, or other specified functions.
topics.label: Supreme court powers

topics.description: In cases where a judge has committed a crime, or otherwise compromised the integrity of their office, he or she may be removed from office. This may be carried out by the legislature, the executive, or another competent body.
topics.label: Supreme/ordinary court judge removal

topics.description: Describes which bodies of government are empowered to interpret the constitution. This is commonly the role of a constitutional court or supreme court, but in some cases is a responsibility of all or a part of the legislature.
topics.label: Constitutional interpretation

topics.description: Procedures for examining whether the content of a piece of legislation is in accord with the constitution. This may or may not be permissible prior to the promulgation of the legislation.
topics.label: Constitutionality of legislation

topics.description: Gives citizens the right to request judicial review of government actions or judgments that they believe have violated their rights.
topics.label: Right to amparo

topics.description: Protects individuals from the use of excess power by administrative agencies of the government. Commonly also establishes procedures for review of such actions and provides redress for those harmed.
topics.label: Ultra-vires administrative actions

topics.description: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve as a judge in an ordinary court. These often concern educational and professional credentials.
topics.label: Eligibility for ordinary court judges

topics.description: The minimum age that an individual must have attained before assuming the office of judge in an ordinary court.
topics.label: Minimum age of ordinary court judges

topics.description: The procedure through which a candidate for an ordinary court judgeship is nominated and approved.  This might involve approval from the executive, and all or part of the legislature.
topics.label: Ordinary court selection

topics.description: The number of years that an ordinary court judge serves before either reappointment or dismissal is required.
topics.label: Ordinary court term length

topics.description: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve as a judge in an ordinary court.
topics.label: Ordinary court term limits

topics.description: Special courts that are empowered to review the actions of public servants acting in their official capacity.
topics.label: Courts for judging public officials

topics.description: Courts that adjudicate disputes about the government's exercise of power in ordinary administrative functions.
topics.label: Establishment of administrative courts

topics.description: A court that is especially empowered to interpret the constitution, and usually to rule on whether legislation is in accord with the principles of the constitution.
topics.label: Establishment of constitutional court

topics.description: Courts that review government actions to determine whether an individual's rights were infringed or violated.
topics.label: Establishment of courts of amparo

topics.description: Establishes a special body to monitor judges. Judicial councils are commonly tasked with reviewing complaints about judges, and are sometimes involved in selecting, promoting, and removing judges.
topics.label: Establishment of judicial council

topics.description: Courts with limited jurisdiction to adjudicate disputes between individuals or trade unions and businesses.
topics.label: Establishment of labor courts

topics.description: Courts with jurisdiction limited to charges against members of the military, and tasked with enforcing military law.
topics.label: Establishment of military courts

topics.description: Courts with limited jurisdiction to adjudicate matters arising in religious law. Jurisdiction may be limited on a confessional basis.
topics.label: Establishment of religious courts

topics.description: Courts with limited jurisdiction to adjudicate disputes between individuals or businesses and the state with regard to taxation.
topics.label: Establishment of tax courts

topics.description: Establishes the basic organization of the judicial branch. In some cases only the highest court is established, leaving further organization to be determined by ordinary legislation.
topics.label: Structure of the courts

topics.description: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve as a judge on the supreme court. These often concern educational and professional credentials.
topics.label: Eligibility for supreme court judges

topics.description: The minimum age that an individual must have attained before assuming the office of judge on the supreme court.
topics.label: Minimum age of supreme court judges

topics.description: Determines procedures for, or treatment of, judicial opinions handed down by the supreme court.
topics.label: Supreme court opinions

topics.description: Establishes the competencies of the supreme court, other than adjudication and review of legislation. Such powers may include supervision of elections, impeachment of the executive, review of treaties, or other specified functions.
topics.label: Supreme court powers

topics.description: The procedure through which a candidate for a supreme court judgeship is nominated and approved.  This might involve approval from the executive, and all or part of the legislature.
topics.label: Supreme court selection

topics.description: The number of years that a supreme court justice serves before either reappointment or dismissal is required.
topics.label: Supreme court term length

topics.description: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve as a judge on the supreme court.
topics.label: Supreme court term limits

topics.description: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve as a representative in the first chamber of the legislature. These often concern residency, proficiency in the official language, or prior occupation.
topics.label: Eligibility for first chamber

topics.description: Specifies the proportion of the seats in the first chamber that must be assigned to representatives of a particular group, such as women, ethnic groups, political parties, religious groups, or social classes.
topics.label: First chamber representation quotas

topics.description: Names specific areas of legislation that are a special concern for the first chamber. This may include sole authority to legislate in these areas.
topics.label: First chamber reserved policy areas

topics.description: Describes the procedure through which members of the first chamber of the legislature are elected or appointed.
topics.label: First chamber selection

topics.description: Names the office that presides over the first chamber of the legislature. This function might be fulfilled by the head of government, a member of the chamber, the deputy executive, or another official.
topics.label: Leader of first chamber

topics.description: The minimum age that an individual must have attained to be eligible to serve as a representative in the first chamber of the legislature.
topics.label: Minimum age for first chamber

topics.description: The total number of seats in the first chamber of the legislature.
topics.label: Size of first chamber

topics.description: The number of years that a representative in the first chamber of the legislature serves before reelection, reappointment, or dismissal is required.
topics.label: Term length for first chamber

topics.description: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve as a representative in the first chamber of the legislature.
topics.label: Term limits for first chamber

topics.description: Identifies which body has the power to approve or reject legislation after it has been passed by the legislature. Some systems do not require this final step.
topics.label: Approval of general legislation

topics.description: Specifies the manner in which the work of the legislative process is divided between the two chambers of the legislature. For example, legislation could be considered concurrently or sequentially, or could be divided on the basis of policy areas.
topics.label: Division of labor between chambers

topics.description: Specifies who has the power to propose new legislation. Beyond members of the legislature, this may or may not be extended to political parties, the general public, the head of government, or the head of state.
topics.label: Initiation of general legislation

topics.description: Particularly vital or contentious policy areas may require a supermajority of a specified size in order to pass legislation.  Although constitutional amendments often require a supermajority, this topic addresses ordinary legislation only.
topics.label: Supermajority required for legislation

topics.description: Allows the legislature to take additional steps to pass legislation that has been vetoed by the actor responsible for approving or rejecting legislation. This typically requires a supermajority, but there is some variation.
topics.label: Veto override procedure

topics.description: Identifies which body has the power to approve or reject legislation after it has been passed by the legislature. Some systems do not require this final step.
topics.label: Approval of general legislation

topics.description: Specifies who has the authority to dismiss the legislature. May also specify the conditions under which this may take place.
topics.label: Dismissal of the legislature

topics.description: Protection, whether absolute or limited, against prosecution for members of the legislature. This may involve protection against prosecution for certain kinds of crimes, or for a specified period of time.
topics.label: Immunity of legislators

topics.description: Procedures for removing individual members of the legislature for crimes or malfeasance. In some cases this action is taken by the legislator's chamber.
topics.label: Removal of individual legislators

topics.description: Establishes the procedure through which a seat in the legislature may be filled in the event that a legislator has been removed from office, resigns, or dies.
topics.label: Replacement of legislators

topics.description: Allows the legislature to take additional steps to pass legislation that has been vetoed by the actor responsible for approving or rejecting legislation. This typically requires a supermajority, but there is some variation.
topics.label: Veto override procedure

topics.description: Requires legislators to attend sessions or votes. Examples include mandatory attendance, punishment after a specified number of absences, or delegating the matter to ordinary law.
topics.label: Attendance by legislators

topics.description: Specifies the actors involved in establishing the compensation of legislators. In addition to the legislature, this might involve the head of state, head of government, an independent commission, or other actors.
topics.label: Compensation of legislators

topics.description: Requires legislators to disclose their income, or the value of their assets. This disclosure is typically made to a specified official or commission, and is not necessarily made public.
topics.label: Earnings disclosure requirement

topics.description: Establishes who has the authority to call an extraordinary session of the legislature, and in some cases what circumstances would allow them to take such action.
topics.label: Extraordinary legislative sessions

topics.description: Provides for the two chambers of a bicameral legislature to meet jointly. This may involve a body made up of both chambers, or a special joint session for specific purposes.
topics.label: Joint meetings of legislative chambers

topics.description: Mechanisms that allow the legislative branch to ensure that executive agencies are enforcing the laws according to the intent of the legislature. Also provides a check on the misuse or abuse of executive power.
topics.label: Legislative oversight of the executive

topics.description: The number of days or months that the legislature meets within a year.
topics.label: Length of legislative sessions

topics.description: May bar legislators from engaging in other occupations during their term in office. Limitations might include prohibitions on holding some or all other public offices, or engaging in private business.
topics.label: Outside professions of legislators

topics.description: Specifies whether the legislature is to conduct its business in public or in private. When legislative sessions are generally public, some constitutions may also specify the conditions (if any) under which the legislature may hold private sessions.
topics.label: Public or private sessions

topics.description: Requires that a written record of the deliberations of the legislature be published.
topics.label: Publication of deliberations

topics.description: The legislature is only permitted to conduct its business, especially to vote on legislation, when a certain percentage of its members are present.
topics.label: Quorum for legislative sessions

topics.description: Establishes the level of transparency in legislative voting. This could be a matter of public record, always kept secret, or varied depending on the topic of the vote.
topics.label: Secrecy of legislative votes

topics.description: Specifies who has the authority to dismiss the legislature. May also specify the conditions under which this may take place.
topics.label: Dismissal of the legislature

topics.description: Protection, whether absolute or limited, against prosecution for members of the legislature. This may involve protection against prosecution for certain kinds of crimes, or for a specified period of time.
topics.label: Immunity of legislators

topics.description: Procedures for removing individual members of the legislature for crimes or malfeasance. In some cases this action is taken by the legislator's chamber.
topics.label: Removal of individual legislators

topics.description: Establishes the procedure through which a seat in the legislature may be filled in the event that a legislator has been removed from office, resigns, or dies.
topics.label: Replacement of legislators

topics.description: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve as a representative in the second chamber of the legislature. These often concern residency, proficiency in the official language, or prior occupation.
topics.label: Eligibility for second chamber

topics.description: Names the office that presides over the second chamber of the legislature. This function might be fulfilled by a member of the chamber, the deputy executive, or another official.
topics.label: Leader of second chamber

topics.description: The minimum age that an individual must have attained to be eligible to serve as a representative in the second chamber of the legislature.
topics.label: Minimum age for second chamber

topics.description: Specifies the proportion of the seats in the second chamber that must be assigned to representatives of a particular group, such as women, ethnic groups, political parties, religious groups, or social classes.
topics.label: Second chamber representation quotas

topics.description: Names specific areas of legislation that are a special concern for the second chamber. This may include sole authority to legislate in these areas.
topics.label: Second chamber reserved policy areas

topics.description: Describes the procedure through which members of the second chamber of the legislature are elected or appointed. This is often different from the selection procedure used for the first chamber.
topics.label: Second chamber selection

topics.description: The total number of seats in the second chamber of the legislature.
topics.label: Size of second chamber

topics.description: The number of years that a representative in the second chamber of the legislature serves before reelection, reappointment, or dismissal is required.
topics.label: Term length of second chamber

topics.description: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve as a representative in the second chamber of the legislature.
topics.label: Term limits of second chamber

topics.description: A requirement that the government pass a budget in which incoming revenue meets or exceeds the value of the government's expenditures in a fiscal year.
topics.label: Balanced budget

topics.description: Special legislative processes for budget bills, which may include restrictions on proposal, approval, or amendment. Budget bills refer to legislation that lays out the revenues and expenditures for some period of time, usually in years.
topics.label: Budget bills

topics.description: Mention of national economic plans, possibly with the procedure for establishing them. Such procedures may include special rules for proposal, approval, or amendment.
topics.label: Economic plans

topics.description: Special legislative processes for finance bills, which may include restrictions on proposal, approval, or amendment. Finance bills refer to legislation specifically for the borrowing of money for governmental use, like loans from NGOs, other countries, or even private individuals.
topics.label: Finance bills

topics.description: Special legislative processes for organic laws, which may include restrictions on proposal, approval, or amendment. Organic laws establish fundamental aspects of the constitutional order, including establishing institutions like the courts or legislature, and in some jurisdictions are accorded similar status to the constitution itself. They sometimes require a higher standard for approval than ordinary law.
topics.label: Organic laws

topics.description: Special legislative processes for spending bills, which may include restrictions on proposal, approval, or amendment. Spending bills refer to legislation specifically for the expenditure of government money.
topics.label: Spending bills

topics.description: Special legislative processes for tax bills, which may include restrictions on proposal, approval, or amendment. Tax bills refer to legislation specifically for collecting revenue for public use, usually in the form of taxes or tariffs.
topics.label: Tax bills

topics.description: The constitution establishes the existence of legislative committees.  Sometimes details on formation and procedure are provided.
topics.label: Legislative committees

topics.description: Establishes permanent committees with oversight in given policy areas, which often exercise legislative authority when the legislature is not in session. May also specify how members of these committees are selected, and how long they serve.
topics.label: Standing committees

topics.description: Establishes the number of chambers in the legislature.
topics.label: Structure of legislative chamber(s)

topics.description: Requires that officials in the public service are recruited and promoted on the basis of merit. This is intended to be a hedge against patronage and nepotism, and may require standardized exams or a specified kind of credential.
topics.label: Civil service recruitment

topics.description: Mention of territory beyond the national borders that is under the government's control. This may include colonies, protectorates, or territories.
topics.label: Colonies

topics.description: Usually in the context of specifying the new regime's treatment of these crimes. May grant amnesty or require punishment.
topics.label: Crimes of the previous regime

topics.description: Frames the constitution in a particular context. Often a response to the country's recent history.
topics.label: Motives for writing constitution

topics.description: Requires certain public office holders to take an oath to support or abide by the constitution.
topics.label: Oaths to abide by constitution

topics.description: Describes ownership of natural resources in general, or makes specific references to ownership or use of energy, mineral, water, flora, fauna, or other natural resources.
topics.label: Ownership of natural resources

topics.description: Reference to historical figures or political theorists. Usually mentioned in the preamble in the context of a particular political tradition.
topics.label: Political theorists/figures

topics.description: References to art or artists indicate the importance of art to the national identity, and are often made in the context of mandating state support for the arts.
topics.label: Reference to art

topics.description: May invoke particular triumphs or tragedies in the country's past. Situates the constitution in the country's larger legal and political identity.
topics.label: Reference to country's history

topics.description: Considered one of the fundamental values of many states. Often mentioned in the preamble as a motivation for the constitution.
topics.label: Reference to fraternity/solidarity

topics.description: Reference to science, which may include prioritization of investment in scientific research, or mandate state support for science and innovation.
topics.label: Reference to science

topics.description: Reference to a group of states, a geographical region, or an intergovernmental organization, such as the European Union.
topics.label: Regional group(s)

topics.description: Establishes the agent with the authority to install the constitution or from which the state derives its ultimate authority. Many constitutions invoke the people, an assembly, a group of subnational units, a monarch, or a deity.
topics.label: Source of constitutional authority

topics.description: A description of the system of government that the constitution is intended to create. Could be a description of the structure of the state, or of the political system.
topics.label: Type of government envisioned

topics.description: Names the official anthem of the state.
topics.label: National anthem

topics.description: Names the capital city of the state.
topics.label: National capital

topics.description: Describes the principal features of the national flag.
topics.label: National flag

topics.description: Affirms the national motto, sometimes in more than one language.
topics.label: National motto

topics.description: An independent commission responsible for facilitating and regulating elections. May be responsible for monitoring political parties and the financing of elections.
topics.label: Electoral commission

topics.description: Establishes the competencies of the electoral court. In addition to hearing challenges of election results, the court may be responsible for certifying various aspects of elections, including voter rolls and final vote tallies.
topics.label: Electoral court powers

topics.description: In cases where a judge has committed a crime, or otherwise compromised the integrity of their office, he or she may be removed from office. This may be carried out by the legislature, the executive, or another competent body.
topics.label: Electoral court removal

topics.description: The procedure through which a candidate for an electoral court judgeship is nominated and approved.  This might involve approval from the executive, and all or part of the legislature.
topics.label: Electoral court selection

topics.description: The number of years that an electoral judge serves before either reappointment or dismissal is required.
topics.label: Electoral court term length

topics.description: The number of terms, either consecutive or in total, that an individual may serve as a judge in an electoral court.
topics.label: Electoral court term limits

topics.description: Qualifications that an individual must meet in order to serve as a judge in an electoral court. These often concern educational and professional credentials.
topics.label: Eligibility for electoral court judges

topics.description: The minimum age that an individual must have attained before assuming the office of judge in the electoral court.
topics.label: Minimum age of electoral court judges

topics.description: Describes which branch or body of the government has the power to regulate political parties, particularly those tasked with determining the unconstitutionality of certain parties.
topics.label: Regulation of political parties

topics.description: Establishes or affirms a central bank. May also include requirements for its governance and operations.
topics.label: Central bank

topics.description: An independent commission specifically empowered to investigate corruption within the government.
topics.label: Counter corruption commission

topics.description: An independent commission responsible for facilitating and regulating elections. May be responsible for monitoring political parties and the financing of elections.
topics.label: Electoral commission

topics.description: Establishes a special body to monitor judges. Judicial councils are commonly tasked with reviewing complaints about judges, and are sometimes involved in selecting, promoting, and removing judges.
topics.label: Establishment of judicial council

topics.description: An independent commission tasked with investigating potential violations of human rights. The commission may be empowered to take action, or may be required to forward its findings to the regular courts.
topics.label: Human rights commission

topics.description: Establishes a commission to regulate mass media. This may include ensuring free expression, and in some cases enforcing some form of censorship.
topics.label: Media commission

topics.description: A public official tasked with investigating improper or illegal actions on the part of government agencies which may infringe on the rights of individuals. Enables individuals to bring complaints about the actions of the government.
topics.label: Ombudsman

topics.description: A special commission tasked with hearing testimony and gathering evidence about human rights violations and other crimes, usually committed by a previous regime. Testimony given in such a commission may or may not be protected from use in future prosecutions.
topics.label: Truth and reconciliation commission

topics.description: Establishes a commission to regulate mass media. This may include ensuring free expression, and in some cases enforcing some form of censorship.
topics.label: Media commission

topics.description: Reference to the wireless transmission of audio programs, usually in the context of regulation.
topics.label: Radio

topics.description: Describes the relationship between the state and the media. This may give the state control over all media, allow the state to operate some media, or prohibit the state from such activities.
topics.label: State operation of the media

topics.description: Reference to wired or wireless communication, and the industries that support it, usually in the context of regulation. Includes telephones, satellites, the internet, and other communication technologies.
topics.label: Telecommunications

topics.description: Reference to the wireless transmission of audio-visual programs, usually in the context of regulation.
topics.label: Television

topics.description: Requires all citizens to be a member of a political party, or of the sole political party of the state.
topics.label: Duty to join a political party

topics.description: Requires all citizens to contribute to the expenses of the state through taxes. This is usually a general statement and may still allow for variation on the basis of income.
topics.label: Duty to pay taxes

topics.description: A duty to serve a specified period of time in the country's military. Often also includes protections for conscientious objectors.
topics.label: Duty to serve in the military

topics.description: Requires individuals to contribute to the betterment of their society through work. This is usually a general statement and may still allow for variation on the basis of disability, age or other factors.
topics.label: Duty to work

topics.description: The right to vote is held by all citizens. There may nevertheless be some restrictions on voting by residency, age, residency or criminal conviction.
topics.label: Claim of universal suffrage

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to gather in groups, in public spaces, for any otherwise legal purpose. This is right is closely associated with the idea of protest.
topics.label: Freedom of assembly

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to form groups or associations for any otherwise legal purpose. This also sometimes includes the right not to join or associate with a group.
topics.label: Freedom of association

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to express their thoughts and feelings without prior censorship or other forms of governmental interference. This right is rarely absolute, and is often limited in cases of sedition, hate speech, or obscenity.
topics.label: Freedom of expression

topics.description: Grants citizens the right to travel and reside anywhere within the state, and to travel to and from other countries. The right does not normally grant non-citizens access to the state.
topics.label: Freedom of movement

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to believe or think anything they find compelling. This does not necessarily mean that they have a right to express these beliefs.
topics.label: Freedom of opinion/thought/conscience

topics.description: Grants individuals, especially journalists and publishers, the right to free expression through all forms of media. In many jurisdictions this includes a protection against prior censorship.
topics.label: Freedom of press

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to hold religious beliefs, and to freely practice those religious beliefs. This right is also commonly understood to include the right to change one's religion, or to have no religion at all.
topics.label: Freedom of religion

topics.description: Considered one of the fundamental values of many states. Often mentioned in the preamble as a motivation for the constitution. Also a justification for some constitutional provisions.
topics.label: Human dignity

topics.description: Recognizes secular marriages performed by a government official or other so empowered individuals, or religious marriages that also involve a license from the state.
topics.label: Provision for civil marriage

topics.description: Grants groups and individuals the right to bring petitions to the government. This includes the right to bring complaints about the actions of the government.
topics.label: Right of petition

topics.description: Allows scholars to pursue their research agenda without undue interference from the state. This is usually understood to also include freedom to teach and publish.
topics.label: Right to academic freedom

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to possess firearms and other weapons. This right may in some jurisdictions still be subject to regulation of the kinds of weapons that can be possessed, and the places and manners in which they may be transported.
topics.label: Right to bear arms

topics.description: Grants individuals whose religious or ethical beliefs prevent them from participating in war an exemption from military service.
topics.label: Right to conscientious objection

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to both develop and express their own unique personality.
topics.label: Right to development of personality

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to commit to one another and raise children together. This right is closely tied to the right to marry. Many constitutions stipulate only a general state duty to protect the family.
topics.label: Right to found a family

topics.description: Grants individuals access to information collected or held by the government, particularly information about oneself, or information of general public interest.
topics.label: Right to information

topics.description: Grants adults the right to enter into a legally recognized, long-term commitment to one another. This may include a definition of marriage, and may or may not be limited to heterosexual couples.
topics.label: Right to marry

topics.description: Grants citizens the right to overthrow the government under certain circumstances. This right is usually expressed in terms of defending the constitutional order, rather than establishing a new one.
topics.label: Right to overthrow government

topics.description: Grants individuals protection against government intrusion into their property, papers, person, or communications without proper authorization. Also protects against such intrusions by private individuals.
topics.label: Right to privacy

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to defend themselves against libel or slander. Understood in the context of freedom of expression, this may not include prior censorship, allowing instead for legal remedy after the fact.
topics.label: Right to protect one's reputation

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to renounce their citizenship. This right is sometimes subject to qualifications relating to dual-citizenship, or the existence of a state of war.
topics.label: Right to renounce citizenship

topics.description: Children are guaranteed certain rights or afforded special protections, which may include state-provided education and healthcare, and/or the right to be free from any kind of abuse.
topics.label: Rights of children

topics.description: Protection for individuals who are unable to repay loans or other financial obligations. The contractual rights of the lender are qualified by the right of the debtor to their freedom or dignity.
topics.label: Rights of debtors

topics.description: Protects individuals and businesses from government confiscation of their property without proper compensation. The level of compensation may be variously specified as fair, full, appropriate, adequate, or otherwise.
topics.label: Protection from expropriation

topics.description: Gives individuals and businesses the exclusive right to protect and profit from their creative works.
topics.label: Provisions for intellectual property

topics.description: Grants individuals the freedom to choose their occupation and their place of employment without interference from the government.
topics.label: Right to choose occupation

topics.description: Protects individuals and businesses from monopolies, price fixing, and other means of reducing competition in the marketplace.
topics.label: Right to competitive marketplace

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to establish for-profit commercial endeavors.
topics.label: Right to establish a business

topics.description: Allows individuals and corporations the sole ownership of real property, effects, financial instruments, or other objects. This right is in some cases open to violation in the interests of the community.
topics.label: Right to own property

topics.description: Grants the right to dispose of property through sale, gift, private wills, or other means.
topics.label: Right to transfer property

topics.description: Courts that review government actions to determine whether an individual's rights were infringed or violated.
topics.label: Establishment of courts of amparo

topics.description: An independent commission tasked with investigating potential violations of human rights. The commission may be empowered to take action, or may be required to forward its findings to the regular courts.
topics.label: Human rights commission

topics.description: Rights that are understood to be unassailable, either because they are fundamental or “natural.”  In some countries, they may be absolute rights, not subject even to qualification.
topics.label: Inalienable rights

topics.description: A public official tasked with investigating improper or illegal actions on the part of government agencies which may infringe on the rights of individuals. Enables individuals to bring complaints about the actions of the government.
topics.label: Ombudsman

topics.description: Gives citizens the right to request judicial review of government actions or judgments that they believe have violated their rights.
topics.label: Right to amparo

topics.description: Clarifies the citizenship status of members of indigenous groups. In some cases indigenous groups may be granted citizenship in a sub-national unit.
topics.label: Citizenship of indigenous groups

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to any disability. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality for persons with disabilities

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their age. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of age

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their creed, belief, or opinions. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of creed or belief

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their financial status or property ownership. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of financial status

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their gender or sex. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of gender

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their language. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of language

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their nationality. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of nationality

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their country or place of origin. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of origin

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their parentage or birth. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of parentage

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their political party membership or political opinions. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of political party

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their race. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of race

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their religion. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of religion

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their sexual orientation. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of sexual orientation

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their skin color. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of skin color

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their social status or origin. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of social status

topics.description: Requires that everyone is treated equally before the law, without regard to their tribe or clan. This may apply to both public and private interactions in some jurisdictions.
topics.label: Equality regardless of tribe or clan

topics.description: Guarantees that all individuals are entitled to the same privileges and immunities. Prohibits favoritism or discrimination to any group. All are considered to be equal before the law.
topics.label: General guarantee of equality

topics.description: Grants indigenous peoples an exemption from taxation by the central government.
topics.label: Indigenous right not to pay taxes
