topics.description: Grants indigenous peoples the right to take part in activities that are illegal for the non-indigenous population.
topics.label: Indigenous right to illegal activities

topics.description: Grants indigenous peoples the right to form political parties on the basis of group identity.
topics.label: Indigenous right to political parties

topics.description: Grants indigenous peoples the right to representation in the central government. This might, for example, involve a seat quota in the legislature.
topics.label: Indigenous right to representation

topics.description: Grants indigenous peoples limited rights to self-government, particularly with regard to issues that affect their territory.
topics.label: Indigenous right to self governance

topics.description: Specifically grants indigenous peoples the right to vote in national elections or referenda.
topics.label: Indigenous right to vote

topics.description: Explicit references to social class. This may be in the context of either outlawing or providing for a system of social classes within the state, or in the context of pursuing socio-economic equality.
topics.label: Mentions of social class

topics.description: Requires the state to offer its protection to one or more of the following vulnerable groups: stateless persons, asylum seekers, or refugees.
topics.label: Protection of stateless persons

topics.description: Gives both spouses the same rights in marriage and family law. This is a separate issue from the general guarantee of gender equality.
topics.label: Provision for matrimonial equality

topics.description: Explains circumstances under which the rights of some individuals or groups may be restricted.
topics.label: Restrictions on rights of groups

topics.description: Establishes the right of individuals to practice their culture. May also require the state to protect or promote cultural rights.
topics.label: Right to culture

topics.description: Establishes a group right to self determination. This may be a reference to the nation as a whole, to groups in other countries, or to a portion of the state's population.
topics.label: Right to self determination

topics.description: Establishes whether or not the rights listed in the constitution are binding on private individuals as well as the state.
topics.label: Binding effect of const rights

topics.description: Requires citizens or public officers to obey the constitution. This primarily applies to individuals in cases where the constitution includes a statement of the duties of citizens or holders of public office.
topics.label: Duty to obey the constitution

topics.description: Details the procedure that must be followed for the state to surrender an individual apprehended on its territory to the government of another state for criminal proceedings. Where permitted, this is usually further regulated through bi-lateral treaties.
topics.label: Extradition procedure

topics.description: Ensures that defendants in criminal trials are entitled to have their cases heard according to the process established by law. This may include specific rights, such as the right to be informed of the charges, the right to counsel, and the right to appeal.
topics.label: Guarantee of due process

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to trial by jury, or more generally provides for citizen participation in the adjudication of guilt in criminal trials.
topics.label: Jury trials required

topics.description: Requires that those adjudicating a criminal trial maintain the posture that the accused is "innocent until proven guilty." This places the burden of proof on the side of the prosecution in the trial.
topics.label: Presumption of innocence in trials

topics.description: Protects individuals from being prosecuted for actions that were not crimes at the time they were committed. Similarly, the sentence imposed cannot be greater than the one that was mandated at the time that the crime was committed.
topics.label: Principle of no punishment without law

topics.description: Requires that the state produce a public registry of the names of those imprisoned. This often serves as a check on arbitrary or unjust imprisonment.
topics.label: Prison registry

topics.description: Grants juveniles charged with crimes special protections in the judicial system. This may include special courts, different sentencing rules, or special detention centers.
topics.label: Privileges for juveniles in criminal process

topics.description: Prohibits the state from charging an individual with an offense for which they have already been acquitted. This does not necessarily prevent the prosecution from appealing an acquittal.
topics.label: Prohibition of double jeopardy

topics.description: Protects individuals from prosecution for acts that were not criminal at the time that they were committed, or from changes in the penalties for acts.
topics.label: Protection from ex post facto laws

topics.description: Provides redress for individuals who have been confined or arrested without just cause, or have otherwise suffered from judicial error.
topics.label: Protection from false imprisonment

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to forego answering questions during an interrogation or in court that would tend to confirm the individual's guilt. In some cases an individual may waive this right if they so choose.
topics.label: Protection from self-incrimination

topics.description: Protects individuals from arbitrary detention or improper arrests. Sometimes specified as a right to a writ of habeas corpus.
topics.label: Protection from unjustified restraint

topics.description: Grants the victims of crime rights in the justice process. These rights may include attendance at the trial, an opportunity to speak at the trial, restitution, or other measures to address the needs of crime victims.
topics.label: Protection of victim's rights

topics.description: Regulates the state's actions with regard to searches and seizures, particularly with regard to criminal investigations. May also prohibit the admission of involuntary confessions, or other suspect forms of evidence.
topics.label: Regulation of evidence collection

topics.description: Gives citizens the right to request judicial review of government actions or judgments that they believe have violated their rights.
topics.label: Right to amparo

topics.description: Gives individuals the right to appeal a judicial decision in a higher court if they are not satisfied with the outcome in the court of first instance. Does not necessarily require the appellate court to hear the case, but the mention of an appellate court may imply the power to appeal.
topics.label: Right to appeal judicial decisions

topics.description: Gives individuals who have been arrested the right to legal counsel. In absence of a right to counsel some constitutions grant only the right to a defense.
topics.label: Right to counsel

topics.description: Grants an accused offender, and their legal counsel, the right to cross-examine evidence or witnesses brought against them by the prosecution.
topics.label: Right to examine evidence/witnesses

topics.description: Protects individuals from unfair procedures. Fair trials often require a public hearing within a reasonable time following the arrest, and judgment by a competent and impartial jury.
topics.label: Right to fair trial

topics.description: Grants individuals who have been arrested and charged with a crime the right to be released from custody until the time of their trial. This may require paying the court a sum of money to be repaid at the time of the trial, or other conditions for release.
topics.label: Right to pre-trial release

topics.description: Grants individuals charged with an offense the right to have their trial held in public.
topics.label: Right to public trial

topics.description: Grants individuals charged with an offense the right to be brought to trial without any undue delay.
topics.label: Right to speedy trial

topics.description: Grants individuals charged with an offense the right to have their trial conducted in a language they understand, or the right to have an interpreter. In some cases, this would include a right to be informed of the reasons for one’s arrest.
topics.label: Trial in native language of accused

topics.description: Forbids the state from employing the death penalty as a punishment for any crime.
topics.label: Prohibition of capital punishment

topics.description: Forbids the state from inflicting physical harm on an offender as a punishment for any crime.
topics.label: Prohibition of corporal punishment

topics.description: Forbids the state from treating individuals in a way that offends the principle of human dignity. This may include forms of corporal or capital punishment, excessive delays in assessing punishment, or other actions prejudicial to the rights of offenders.
topics.label: Prohibition of cruel treatment

topics.description: Forbids the practice of owning or otherwise exploiting human beings. May still allow for compulsory labor as a punishment for a crime, and/or compulsory service in the military in time of war.
topics.label: Prohibition of slavery

topics.description: Forbids the state from torturing individuals, and in some cases from using coerced statements in court.  This prohibition may be limited in cases of war or other circumstances.
topics.label: Prohibition of torture

topics.description: Establishes a right to life. The precise meaning of this provision varies between jurisdictions, and may or may not be a reference to the unborn.
topics.label: Right to life

topics.description: Guarantees individuals equal access to higher education. In some cases this may be limited on a competitive basis, or by tests of aptitude.
topics.label: Access to higher education

topics.description: Requires children to attend school. This may be a requirement up to a certain age, or to a certain level of educational attainment.
topics.label: Compulsory education

topics.description: Requires the state to provide education free of charge. This may be limited at a certain age or level of educational attainment.
topics.label: Free education

topics.description: Protects children against exploitation in the workplace. This may be in the form of a ban on child workers, or as a requirement for additional protections for child workers.
topics.label: Limits on employment of children

topics.description: Addresses consumer rights or consumer protection. Protects consumers from harmful products and/or predatory or unethical business practices.
topics.label: Protection of consumers

topics.description: Imposes a duty on the state or on the people to protect or conserve the environment. This may also accord to citizens the right to enjoy a healthy environment.
topics.label: Protection of environment

topics.description: Accords individuals the right to enjoy the benefits of scientific progress, or obligates the state to promote scientific advancement for the benefit of society.
topics.label: Right to enjoy the benefits of science

topics.description: Prohibits employers from paying their employees at differing rates for the same work. A right to just remuneration.
topics.label: Right to equal pay for work

topics.description: Obligates the state to provide health care to its citizens, or provides individuals with the general right to health care.  In some cases, health care must be provided by the government free of charge.
topics.label: Right to health care

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to form and join trade unions or professional associations. This is an explicit right that goes beyond freedom of association.
topics.label: Right to join trade unions

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to a standard of living that sustains human dignity. May also refer to adequate well-being, suitable existence, or life worthy of a human being.
topics.label: Right to reasonable standard of living

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to vacations, weekly holidays, and/or annual paid vacation.
topics.label: Right to rest and leisure

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to work in environment free of preventable hazards. This may include an obligation on the state to provide safe working conditions.
topics.label: Right to safe work environment

topics.description: Grants individuals the right to adequate shelter or housing. Often framed in terms of facilitating family life.
topics.label: Right to shelter

topics.description: Grants individuals and groups the right to cease work for a period of time, in an effort to exert pressure on their employer. This may or may not include protection for the jobs of strikers.
topics.label: Right to strike

topics.description: Gives citizens a general right to work, and/or obligates the state to provide work. This is distinct from the right to choose one's occupation.
topics.label: Right to work

topics.description: Obligates the state to provide financial or material resources to children.
topics.label: State support for children

topics.description: Obligates the state to provide financial or material resources to persons with disabilities.
topics.label: State support for the disabled

topics.description: Obligates the state to provide financial or material resources to elderly persons.
topics.label: State support for the elderly

topics.description: Obligates the state to provide financial or material resources to unemployed persons.
topics.label: State support for the unemployed

topics.description: An introductory section which may or may not be considered an enforceable part of the constitution.
topics.label: Preamble

topics.description: Temporary sections of the constitution that guide the transition from the previous system to the current constitutional order.
topics.label: Transitional provisions
